Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Unsteady Hydrodynamics and Geometric Control of Pisciform Locomotion

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative project will improve the state-of-the-art of physical models and control design methods for propulsion and control in fluids, through the study of pisciform locomotion -- that is, through the study of movement strategies used by fishlike animals. The project balances fundamental analysis, numerical simulation, and physical experiments. A cornerstone of the effort is the development of a modular biolocomotion emulator (MBE) that can be configured to demonstrate the full spectrum of distinct pisciform strategies, from oscillatory locomotion (used, for example, by tuna) to undulatory locomotion (used, for example, by eels). The results will advance the capabilities of engineered systems, towards the astonishing capabilities for speed, agility, stealth, robustness, and efficiency seen in fishlike animals.

Previous models of pisciform locomotion have largely relied on quasi-steady flow assumptions that fail to capture important unsteady interactions between the body and the fluid. This effort will formulate, identify and validate a low-dimensional, state space model for unsteady flow effects and incorporate that model into a geometric control framework that enables the design of optimum morphologies and gaits. Specifically, the research program will produce (i) an assessment of the unsteady vortex lattice method (UVLM) as a tool for modeling pisciform locomotion, (ii) an experimentally validated, reduced-order state space representation for the unsteady forces on a series of moving foils in a flow, (iii) methods for optimizing the morphology and gait of a pisciform swimmer using a geometric control model that has been amended to include unsteady flow effects, and (iv) a parametric repository of motion, force, and visualization data from towing experiments using the MBE.

Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: VIRGINIA POLYTECHNIC INSTITUTE AND STATE UNIVERSITY

Performance_Institution.Name: Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaboration between the University of California at Irvine (UC-Irvine) and Virginia Tech integrated theoretical and computational analysis, led by Prof. Haithem Taha at UC-Irvine, with experimental and computational analysis led by Profs. Craig Woolsey and Muhammad Hajj at Virginia Tech. The focus of this analysis was reduced order modeling of the fluid/structure interactions in pisciform (fishlike) locomotion with the aim of supporting the design and control of biomimetic swimming robots. The effort led by Prof. Taha (companion grant no. CMMI-1635673) focused on the formulation and identification of reduced order state space models that capture unsteady hydrodynamic effects while remaining amenable to geometric control design and analysis. The Virginia Tech effort focused on the collection and analysis of experimental hydrodynamic data to validate these low-order control-oriented models. We developed a test article called the Modular Biomimetic Emulator (MBE) and obtained force and moment data in the Virginia Tech towing basin for a variety of gaits (waveforms and frequencies) over a range of towing speeds. The results provide useful insight concerning the propulsive force and efficiency associated with the various gaits that were tested, but they have greater value as validation data for computational analysis methods. The data are available for download from a web-based repository. Late in the research program, an opportunity arose to repeat the MBE experiments in a larger towing basin. The MBE was redesigned for this purpose with greater performance capability and improved instrumentation. At the time of this report, a team of student researchers is preparing to execute a test program at this alternate facility with the aim of expanding and improving the data available to other researchers on the project website.


Last Modified: 12/23/2020
Modified by: Craig Woolsey
